unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Cereal Boxes
question_text: A spokesman for a large cereal company is interested in whether a new promotion of including a toy in every box of cereal would greatly increase sales. He figures that age would be a factor, so he selects one pair of subjects at each age range from $10$ to $79$ by increments of $5\text{ years}$ . The spokesman flips a coin to decide which of the pair gets a coupon for a free prize every time they buy a box of the cereal. After one year, each subject is asked how many boxes of that brand of cereal they bought. The data is in the table below ( scroll right to see full table ): Age Range 10- 14 15- 19 20- 24 24- 29 30- 34 35- 39 40- 44 45- 49 50- 54 55- 59 60- 64 65- 69 70- 74 75-79 With Coupon 9 8 8 5 4 12 14 13 8 6 5 4 4 2 Without Coupon 7 4 8 6 5 7 8 7 6 6 4 3 4 1 From this data, is there convincing statistical evidence that people buy more cereal when a prize coupon is included?

choices.text: Yes, at the 1 % 1 % , 5 % 5 % , and 10 % 10 % alpha levels.
Yes, at the 5 % 5 % and 10 % 10 % alpha level, but not the 1 % 1 % level.
Yes, at the 10 % 10 % alpha level, but not the 5 % 5 % or 1 % 1 % levels.
No, not at none of the common alpha levels of 1 % 1 % , 5 % 5 % , or 10 % 10 % .
Yes, since the mean of the “with prize” is above the mean of the “without prize.”
